I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2005 Country Programming Mission, the Government of the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) requested the assistance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to prepare two 
projects: (i) the Henan Ecological Agriculture and Rural Productivity Improvement Project, and 
(ii) the Central and Southern Shanxi Integrated Agricultural Development Project. This project 
preparatory technical assistance (TA)1 will prepare the projects to meet (i) the PRC’s goals of 
improving sustainable rural economic growth and poverty reduction, and (ii) ADB’s goal of poverty 
reduction. The TA Fact-finding Mission was fielded from 13 to 20 April 2006 in Henan province 
and from 21 to 25 April 2006 in Shanxi province. This report is based on (i) the findings of the 
Mission; and (ii) the understandings reached with the Government on the objectives, scope, 
terms of reference, implementation arrangements, and cost estimates for the TA. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC’s rapid economic growth over the past 15 years has increased incomes and 
reduced poverty. However, rural income growth has lagged behind urban income growth, leaving 
widening income differentials between rural and urban areas and between eastern, central, and 
western regions of the country. In its Eleventh Five-Year Plan, the Government places a high 
priority on reducing rural-urban income differences through its New Socialist Countryside Policy.2 
The policy prioritizes investment in (i) improving rural growth, (ii) increasing farm productivity to 
raise rural incomes, and (iii) carrying out environmentally sustainable production.  
 
3.  Henan province’s Sanmenxia municipality has a rural population of 2.2 million (72% of the 
municipality’s total population). This population depends on agriculture for a living. Sanmenxia is 
located in the transition zone from PRC’s northern plains to the loess plateau region, and its 
sloped areas are complexly fragmented, with most production taking place on small plots on 
slopes, terraces, and riverside areas. These conditions contribute to the municipality’s low rural 
incomes and 7% of the rural population lives on less than CNY7 per capita per day. The options 
for high productivity arable production are limited, but the municipality’s agro-climatic conditions 
are suited to fruit orchards and fast-growing tree species. In order to raise rural productivity and 
incomes  in  Sanmenxia,  cropping  patterns  need  to  change  so  farms  are  linked  to  reliable 
markets.3 
 
4.  Shanxi  province  has  only  1.07  million  hectares  of  dependable  cultivated  land  for  its 
23 million farmers. Like Sanmenxia, southern and central Shanxi are located in the transition 
zone to the loess plateau and face similar productivity constraints. The area is bordered by the 
Yellow River and a number of tributaries, and valleys and flood flats are important production 
areas. In the target 26 counties in the five prefectural-level municipalities of Changzhi, Jinzhong, 
Linfen, Luliang, and Yuncheng, the per capita land area is less than 0.17 hectares. The average 
2004 annual net income in the province’s designated poor areas is about CNY1,615, CNY683 
lower  than  the  provincial  average.  Across  the  province,  the  average  urban  net  income  is 
CNY7,005, compared with average rural incomes of CNY2,299, giving an urban-rural income 
ratio of 3:1. There is a need to improve the use and management of flood flats, valley areas, and 
marginal lands, and to rehabilitate degraded lands to raise land productivity and returns from farm 
output. Better links to markets through local processing industries and the development of value 
chains will further raise farm incomes and create additional nonfarm employment. 
 
                                                 
1   The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 20 July 2006. 
2  The Policy was officially disclosed on 21 February 2006 by the PRC’s State Council and the Central Committee of 
the Communist Party. 
3  The PRC is the world’s leading producer of deciduous fruit and dominates world trade in apples and apple juice 
concentrate. Last year, the PRC’s apple production was 21 million tons, of which 1 million tons were exported.  The 
PRC has 60% of world trade in apple juice concentrate, half of which goes to the United States. The industry is 
expanding (it grew by 20% in 2005) and there has been heavy investment in modern processing technology and a 
dramatic consolidation of orchard systems, both by agroprocessors leasing state farm land or organizing group 
small-farmer contracts. Western Henan and southern Shanxi are major production bases for the high-acidic type 
apples favored for juice processing.

2   
5.  In addition to the inherent low fertility of loess soils, other environmental problems are 
caused by (i) the declining organic matter content of soils because of inappropriate cultivation 
practices that have left soils susceptible to rain and wind erosion, (ii) overuse of fertilizers and 
pesticides, (iii) alkaline wastelands, and (iv) damage from windborne dust from coalmining (in 
Shanxi province). In Henan’s Sanmenxia municipality and across Shanxi province, shortages of 
water (13% of the PRC average) arise from low average annual rainfall (400 mm–650 mm) 
concentrated in July–September and high evaporation rates. To stabilize the soil and to increase 
farm  output  in  Henan’s  Sanmenxia  municipality,  environmentally  sustainable  strategies  are 
needed to improve incomes by developing orchards and tree crops on eroded, flat, and sloping 
land. To improve use of riverside areas, marginal lands in valley areas, and alkaline wastelands 
in central and southern Shanxi province, investments are needed to develop and rehabilitate 
medium- and low-yielding land and to conserve land and water resources. 
 
6.  A further constraint on farm income growth in both provinces is limited access by farmers 
to environmentally safe technologies that would increase productivity and produce outputs that 
meet the standards and demands of markets. Farmers have limited access to technical advice or 
support services and some of the varieties demanded by processors and end markets are not 
available. Farm production and agro-enterprises must (i) meet the grades and standards required 
by the domestic urban markets, especially those of the growing number of supermarket chains; 
and (ii) meet the phytosanitary requirements of international export markets. Farmers and agro-
enterprises need information on standards for food safety requirements and safe agricultural 
chemical use, and regulations on agro-chemical use. To address the limited capacity of public 
extension services to provide market information and to transfer technology that is relevant to the 
rapidly changing market, provincial and local governments are investigating alternative ways of 
providing services, including using agro-enterprises to provide information directly to farmers and 
developing farmers’ associations to organize farmers.  
 
7.  Farmers have limited access to finance and especially term lending for investment in 
improved technology and production expansion. The rural finance system is reluctant to lend to 
small farmers and rural agro-enterprises because of the perceived risks of lending to the rural 
sector, most farmers’ lack of collateral, and the absence of systems providing information on 
borrowers. The formal rural financial system is not sufficiently developed to provide sustainable 
outreach to farmers and enterprises. Currently, most rural finance is channeled through local 
government financial bureaus, although local governments believe there is potential to supply 
finance to farmers through established agro-enterprises linked to supply contracts.  
 
8.  A critical constraint to raising farm incomes is the shortage of value-adding opportunities 
because  of  lack  of  access  to  viable  agro-processing  and  marketing  enterprises,  and  high 
transaction costs in the value chain. Growth of agro-enterprises is also constrained by limited 
agricultural raw material supply. Such over or under supply of raw materials reflects processing 
enterprise-farmer coordination failures in some cases. In other cases, limited processing capacity 
reflects the failure of financial markets to meet the investment needs of small- and medium-sized 
agro-enterprises. Thus, both farmers and agro-enterprises find it difficult to expand access to the 
PRC’s growing urban and export markets. Nevertheless, there are viable private agro-enterprises 
in the project area that are successfully reaching domestic and export markets for fruit-based and 
other agro-products and are creating nonfarm employment and such success has the potential for 
being expanded and replicated. 
 
9.  Henan  province’s  Sanmenxia  municipality  and  Shanxi  province  are  considering  two 
models to overcome information, coordination, and financial market constraints: (i) an “enterprise-
farmers  associations-production  base”  approach,  and  (ii)  an  “enterprise-production  base” 
approach.4  These  models  will  aim  to  improve  input  supply,  provide  financing  and  technical 
                                                 
4  The “enterprise-farmers associations-production base” model will be used where agro-enterprises will link backwards 
to large numbers of farmers through a formal intermediary such as a farm association. The “enterprise-production 
base” approach will be used where processing enterprises will link backwards directly to a manageable number of 
farmers.

3
information,  and  guarantee  markets.  Equitable  and  monitorable  contracts  between  agro-
enterprises and farmers, and technical support for farmers are needed to improve processing 
enterprise-farmer coordination. Application of the models will require investment in (i) changed 
cropping patterns, (ii) sustainable production methods, (iii) agro-processing capacity expansion, 
and (iv) a stronger information and regulatory service capacity. 
 
10.  Initiatives to raise farm incomes will benefit from (i) strong local government support for 
PRC’s New Socialist Countryside Policy (which is reflected in new agriculture sector development 
plans for Henan and Shanxi provinces), (ii) the successful development of agro-enterprises, (iii) a 
sound concept of linking farmer households with markets through successful agro-enterprises, 
and  (iv)  the  potential  to  develop  corporate  social  responsibility  toward  farmers  and  the 
environment.  
 
11.  The Government recognizes that thorough market analyses are a prerequisite for viable 
lending to private agro-enterprises and farmers. Lessons from ongoing ADB support to the West 
Henan  Agricultural  Development  Project5  show  the  importance  of  avoiding  a  predetermined 
supply-driven approach to enterprise selection and planning. World Bank (WB) support to agro-
enterprises in Shanxi has highlighted the need to understand changing market conditions and to 
avoid selecting underperforming state-owned and small new agro-enterprises, which have a high 
risk of failure.6 Selection criteria for agro- and farm-enterprises will include (i) the viability of 
markets, (ii) the economic feasibility of the enterprises, (iii) principles of equity and fairness in the 
selection process, and (iv) the extent to which private  agro-enterprises will actively support 
environmental sustainability and the objective of improving farmers’ incomes. The Government 
supports efforts to explore innovative ways of reaching poor and low-income farmers, including 
involving private sector enterprises to solve market and institutional constraints while promoting 
good governance and social responsibility.7 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome8 
12.  The  TA  will  appraise  the  Henan  and  Shanxi  governments’  sector  analyses,  plans, 
capacity and proposals, and solutions. This will form the basis for assisting the Government to 
prepare two projects for two separate loans. The impact of the TA is expected to be the 
outcome of these loan projects, i.e., improvements in rural on-farm productivity and market links 
in an ecologically sustainable and pro-poor manner. The projects will involve both public and 
private sectors and build on their relative strengths. The analytical and design work carried out 
under the TA will center on (i) improving land and environmental management in low-yielding 
flat and hilly areas, exploitable riverside areas, and other degraded lands using improved crop 
and livestock production mixes and methods, soil improving technologies, and greater use of 
tree crops; (ii) improving incentives to farmers by facilitating the rural value chain and focusing 
on high-value agricultural products demanded by local private agro-enterprises (thus linking 
farmers to domestic and export markets); and (iii) identifying ways to reduce transaction costs in 
the  value  chain  by  addressing  information,  coordination,  and  finance  constraints  faced  by 
farmers and agro-enterprises.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Henan province’s Sanmenxia municipality and Shanxi province have prepared proposals 
to address rural poverty and rural environmental problems using the models described above

(para. 9). The designs in each province follow a sustainable rural value chain improvement 
approach and improved service delivery by linking agro-enterprises with the production base 
through  better  organization  of  farmers  and  farm  households.  Proposed  activities  include 
(i) improving  land  and  water  use  in  hills  and  valleys  using  better  production  methods,  soil 
improving  technologies,  water  conservation  methods,  greater  use  of  tree  crops,  and  more 
efficient use of animal wastes and organic fertilizers; (ii) facilitating access to markets by farmers 
and securing raw  material supplies by investing in the production base through local agro-
enterprises; (iii) improving coordination between farmers and agro-enterprises by establishing 
and  strengthening  farmer  associations;  and  (iv)  extending  the  adoption  of  environmentally 
sustainable and safe food production by strengthening monitoring, regulation, and information 
dissemination.  
 
14.  The TA will (i) appraise each province’s proposals, (ii) assess the sector analysis and the 
assumptions upon which the proposals are based, (iii) complete sector and market analyses as 
needed, (iv) compare alternative approaches to meeting project goals and desired outcomes, and 
(v) identify design improvements as needed. Specific analyses will include (i) validation of market 
analysis for target enterprises; (ii) identification of technical improvements to soil and water 
management  and  ways  to  mitigate  the  environmental  impact  from  agricultural  production; 
(iii) assessment of constraints and options for accessing rural finance by agro-enterprises and 
farmers; (iv) assessment of existing and potential ways to improve agro-enterprise and farmer 
coordination through farmers’ associations and improved government extension services; (v) 
appraisal of sample sub-projects; and (vi)  analysis of the financial, economic, environmental, and 
poverty and social impacts of the proposed projects.9 The TA is divided into two components, 
responding to the particular needs of the provinces concerned. Component A will address the 
proposal from Sanmenxia municipality in Henan province to improve ecological agriculture and 
raise productivity. Component B will address the proposal from Shanxi province for integrated 
agriculture development in valley areas.  
 
15.  Each component will have two phases. Two major outputs are expected under phase 1: 
(i) a  sector  and  subsector  situation  analysis,  with  accompanying  technical,  economic,  and 
institutional assessments; and (ii) agreement on the project rationale, scope, and approach. The 
work carried out under phase 1 will need to (i) confirm that the Government’s proposals address 
the binding constraints in the sector, (ii) assess proposed solutions and compare them with 
alternatives, (iii) demonstrate the economic rationale for the proposed investment as a public 
sector operation in terms of addressing failures or limitations of markets, and (iv) prepare the 
subproject selection criteria. Phase 2 will be based on the successful delivery of the outputs 
under phase 1 and will cover the activities leading to the design of the investment projects. The 
proposed investment projects will seek to maximize benefits to small-scale farmers and ensure 
links to markets through viable agro-enterprises. Assessments related to ADB requirements, for 
example, on relevant safeguard policies triggered, will be addressed throughout the study. During 
phase  2,  (i)  the  institutional  capacity,  including  the  financial  management  capacity  of  the 
Executing Agency (EA) and implementing agencies, will be evaluated; (ii) project costs will be 
prepared;  and  (iii)  the  economic  and  financial  feasibility  of  the  projects  will  be  assessed. 
Throughout both phases, ADB’s project performance management system guidelines and ADB’s 
Guidelines  on  Project  Design  and  Monitoring  Framework  will  be  followed,  and  effective 
stakeholder consultation and participation will be carried out. Key activities for each output are 
included in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,250,000. ADB was requested to finance 
$1,000,000, comprising $500,000 for preparing the Henan (Sanmenxia) project and $500,000 for 
the Shanxi project. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from ADB’s TA Special Funds 
resources. The governments of Henan (Sanmenxia municipality) and Shanxi will each provide in-
kind contributions of $125,000 for office space, counterpart staff, site transportation, and other

services. Details of the cost estimates for each component are provided in Appendix 3. The 
Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The EA for component A will be the Sanmenxia municipal government. The “project 
leading group” has been established and will be chaired by the vice mayor and will consist of the 
Municipal  Development  and  Reform  Committee,  Municipal  Finance  Bureau,  Forest  Bureau, 
Environment  Protection  Bureau,  Agriculture  Bureau,  Hubin  district,  and  Ling  Bao  city. 
Representatives from these agencies will comprise the project management office. The agro-
enterprises will manage day-to-day implementation activities with farmers. The EA for component 
B will be the Shanxi provincial government headed by another leading group and a provincial 
project management office based in the Poverty Alleviation Office to provide overall supervision 
and monitoring. Changzhi, Jinzhong, Linfen, Luliang, and Yuncheng municipalities and the 26 
project  counties  have  established  a  project  management  structure.  The  municipalities  and 
counties will be the implementing agencies.  
 
18.  The  two  components  will  be  implemented  independently  through  separate  contracts.  
Under component A (Henan Sanmenxia), consulting services will consist of six international 
consultants for 16.5 person-months and six national consultants for 18 person-months. Under 
component  B  (Shanxi),  consulting  services  will  consist  of  six  international  consultants  for 
16 person-months  and  six  national  consultants  for  19  person-months.  The  outline  terms  of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 4. The consultants will be selected and engaged by 
ADB using the quality- and cost-based selection method in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants. Equipment (notebook computers, facsimile machines, and photocopiers) 
will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. For components A and B, the 
consultants will submit (i) inception reports 4 weeks after their services start, (ii) interim progress 
reports at appropriate stages of TA implementation, (iii) draft final reports before the conclusion of 
the contract, and (iv) final reports 2 weeks after incorporating the EAs’ and ADB's comments.10 
Component A will commence in September 2006 and will be completed in June 2007, while 
Component B will begin in October 2006 and be completed in August 2007. ADB will field 
supervision and support missions for TA milestones including TA inception, the midterm review, 
draft final report review and project loan fact-finding, and project appraisal.  
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Henan Ecological Agriculture 
and Rural Productivity Improvement Project and the Central and Southern Shanxi Integrated 
Agricultural Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the People’s Republic of China:  
 
The contribution of the agriculture sector to poverty reduction is recognized in the Government’s Eleventh Five-Year 
Plan, and, as a result, the plan prioritizes rural development, through the New Socialist Countryside Policy.  The policy 
aims to reduce rural-urban income disparities and seeks balanced development by increasing farm productivity and 
farmers’ incomes and by promoting sustainable rural growth and development. The agribusiness and agro-processing 
subsectors are seen by the Government as a means for reducing rural poverty by linking between rural people and 
markets. By actively developing farmers’ associations as the link between producers and agro-enterprises, the low-
income and poor farm households are expected to be empowered in their negotiations with agro-enterprises as 
suppliers of inputs and purchasers of outputs.   
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Given the expected outcome of the resulting loans (improving rural on-farm productivity and market links in an 
ecologically sustainable and pro-poor manner), the technical assistance (TA) will also analyze links between poverty 
and natural resource management. In particular, the rural sociologist/farmers’ organization specialist will identify the 
formal and informal arrangements that govern the use of land and water resources, including common resources. The 
specialist will also map resource use in the project area in terms of purpose, intensity of use, access by different 
segments of the farming community, and analyze the dynamics of poverty in terms of marginalization and access to 
resources. 
 
The TA will be required to prepare a poverty and social assessment of the beneficiaries and stakeholders using the 
Asian Development Bank’s Guidelines on Poverty and Social Assessment. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
The TA will undertake a stakeholder analysis. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
The TA will develop a participation strategy. The TA rural sociologist/farmer organization specialist will provide inputs 
to the design of a participatory monitoring system to track project implementation and use of resources, including a 
mechanism for recourse to address grievances. The TA will also analyze the role of farmers’ organizations in the 
project in increasing farmers’ participation in the project in order to increase the benefits from farmers’ participation in 
the rural value chain. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
The TA rural sociologist/farmer organization specialist will provide inputs to project design to address issues identified 
in  the  problem  analysis,  and  the  social  and  poverty  assessment.  The  specialist  is  expected  to  include 
recommendations on the most appropriate way of ensuring equitable participation of women in decision-making and 
planning of development activities.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will appraise the Henan and Shanxi governments’ sector 
analyses,  plans,  capacity  and  proposals,  and  solutions  as  the  basis  for  assisting  the 
Government to prepare two projects for two separate loans. The impact of the TA is expected to 
be the outcome of the resulting loan projects, which will be to improve rural on-farm productivity 
and market links in the project areas in an ecologically sustainable and pro-poor manner. The 
approach  will  partner  public  and  private  sectors  to  build  on  their  relative  strengths.  The 
analytical and design work carried out under the TA will center on (i) improving the land 
resource and ecological base in low-yield flat and hilly areas, exploitable riverside areas, and 
other degraded lands using improved crop and livestock production mixes and methods, soil 
improving technologies, and greater use of tree crops; (ii) improving incentives to farmers by 
facilitating development of the rural value chain by focusing on high-value agricultural products 
demanded by local private agro-enterprises that effectively link to domestic and export markets; 
and  (iii)  identifying  ways  to  reduce  transaction  costs  in  the  value  chain  by  addressing 
information, coordination, and finance constraints faced by farmers and agro-enterprises. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
2.  Team  and  Deputy  Leader  and  Agribusiness  Specialists.  The  international  team 
leader  (Henan/Sanmenxia,  5  person-months;  Shanxi,  5  person-months),  together  with  a 
national deputy team leader (Henan/Sanmenxia, 5 person-months; Shanxi, 5 person-months), 
will have demonstrated experience in managing agricultural projects in the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) and understanding of the PRC’s agricultural conditions and policies. They will 
carry out the following activities:1  
 
(i)  conduct day-to-day field management of the TA and coordinate with the PRC 
counterparts in government and in business, solve TA management issues as they 
arise, in a way that is consistent with the PRC’s institutional environment; 
(ii)  lead, coordinate, and supervise the consulting team, ensuring TA resources are 
effectively  used,  and  coordinated  with  counterpart  agencies  and  the  operating 
environment, ensuring that an appropriate consultation and participation process is 
followed in line with the guidelines of the Asian Development Bank (ADB);   
(iii)  organize a review of the government’s project proposals and feasibility studies and 
consolidate the team’s response; 
(iv)  lead  the  overall  sector  review,  identify  areas  for  further  analysis  and  overall 
problem tree analysis; 
(v)  identify lessons learned from similar ongoing or completed ADB and World Bank 
projects in Henan and Shanxi provinces and elsewhere in the PRC; 
(vi)  coordinate the review and collection of baseline data for the project areas by the 
rural sociologist and agricultural economist;   
(vii)  analyze, with the agricultural economists, the basic material flows in the supply 
chain from farmland through processing to final marketing for prospective farm 
products, cost the agro-processing supply chain from farmland to final marketing, 
and  identify  physical  and  institutional  factors  that  affect  transaction  costs  and 
distribution of profits, including the enabling environment;  
(viii)  identify and analyze, with the agricultural economists, factors, and stakeholders in 
the supply and value  chain, including factors that are changing domestic and 
export markets (e.g., supermarkets, export markets for fruit products); 
(ix)  identify  critical  needs  for  lowering  transactions  costs  in  the  supply  chain  and 
improving access to markets and recommend necessary institutional and incentive-
related improvements to realizing reduced costs and improved market access; 
(x)  assess  existing  institutional  capacity  and  alternative  organizational  structures 
needed to support and facilitate from the coordination of many small-scale farmers 
to supply modern agro-processing business, and identify capacity development 
needs to support and expand arrangements in line with proposed production base 
                                                 
1  In preparing the problem analysis, project design framework, and the monitoring and evaluation system, the 
consultant should refer to ADB’s Guidelines for Preparing a Design and Monitoring Framework.

12    Appendix 4 
expansions; together with the rural sociologist and farmers’ organization specialists 
and counterparts, identify the most appropriate and effective agro-enterprise and 
farmer coordination arrangements; 
(xi)  review  the  proposed  private  sector  enterprise  contributions  to  the  project  and 
elaborate on the nature, scope, feasibility, and arrangements for public-private 
partnerships; 
(xii)  together with the rural financial specialists, assess the viability of candidate farm 
and agro-enterprises; 
(xiii)  prepare selection criteria for farm and agro-enterprises to be considered for loan 
funding under the Project; 
(xiv)  assume overall responsibility for direction and consolidation of the findings of the 
consulting  team  during  progress,  and  take  ultimate  responsibility  for  the  final 
report; and  
(xv)  prepare the project management, monitoring, and impact evaluation system. 
 
3.  Land,  Soils,  and  Agronomy  Specialists  (Shanxi).  An international  land  and soils 
specialist (Shanxi, 2 person-months) with formal qualifications in agronomy and experience in 
the PRC in land and water assessment in relation to developing sustainable and economic land 
management  systems  in  orchards,  grains,  legumes,  and  vegetable  production  systems, 
together with a qualified national agronomist (Shanxi, 3 person-months) with experience in tree 
crops, and vegetable and grains production will do the following:   
 
(i)  assess the impact of  current production methods on land resources (soil and 
water) and consequently the achievement of yield potential, product quality, water 
usage, and wider environmental impacts such as river siltation, eutrophication, 
groundwater pollution, and land biodiversity; 
(ii)  understand reasons for existing land degradation in the project cropping areas 
(including alkalinity, acidification, erosion, and organic matter decline) and assess 
whether proposed rehabilitation approaches are feasible and sustainable; 
(iii)  collaborate with the environment specialists in analyzing the environmental impact 
of proposed production practices, especially drilling of new wells and use of agro-
chemicals,  and  identify  ways  to  minimize  the  polluting  effects  of  production, 
including identifying organic production methods; 
(iv)  identify  alternative  land  and  water  management  practices  for  proposed  farm 
enterprises to achieve improved water use efficiencies and sustainable land use 
methods such as plant residue retention, no-till, cover crops, intercropping, low-
water requirement orchard varieties, and rainwater harvesting with micro-irrigation 
and fertigation;  
(v)  identify sustainable technologies for drawing, applying, and retaining water in areas 
proposed  for  expanded  production  to  supplement  and  enhance  existing 
conservation techniques; 
(vi)  using the team set of skills, support the reverse analysis of the value chain from 
final demand to determine what interventions in terms of agronomic practices are 
suitable, optimal, and sustainable; 
(vii)  review  current  practices,  past  experiences  in  the  project  region,  and  evaluate 
lessons learned for future planning; and  
(viii)  support  the  agricultural  economists  in  assessing  and  comparing  viable  farm 
practice alternatives. 
 
4.  Tree Crops Agronomists (Henan). An international tree crops agronomist (Henan, 
2 person-months)  with  formal  qualifications  in  agronomy  and  experience  in  developing 
economies in dry fruit growing areas, together with a qualified national tree crops agronomist 
(Henan, 3 person-months) will do the following:   
 
(i)  assess the impact of current annual and tree crop production methods for on-land 
resources (soil and water) and, consequently, the achievement of yield potential, 
product  quality,  water  usage,  and  wider  environmental  impacts,  such  as  river 
siltation, eutrophication, groundwater pollution, and land biodiversity; 
(ii)  review  current  practices,  past  experiences  in  the  project  region,  and  evaluate 
lessons learned for future planning;

Appendix 4  13
     
(iii)  understand reasons for existing land degradation in the project cropping areas 
(including alkalinity, acidification, erosion, and organic matter decline) and assess 
whether proposed tree crop production approaches are feasible and sustainable; 
(iv)  collaborate with the environment specialists in analyzing the environmental impact 
of proposed tree crop production practices, especially drilling of new wells and use 
of agro-chemicals, and identify ways to minimize the polluting effects of production, 
including identifying organic production methods; 
(v)  identify alternative land and water management practices for tree crop enterprises 
to achieve improved water use efficiencies and sustainable land use methods such 
as plant residue retention, no-till, cover crops, intercropping, low-water requirement 
orchard varieties, and rainwater harvesting with micro-irrigation and fertigation; 
(vi)  identify sustainable technologies for drawing, applying, and retaining water in areas 
proposed  for  expanded  production  to  supplement  and  enhance  existing 
conservation techniques; using the team set of skills, support the reverse analysis 
of the value chain from final demand to determine what interventions in terms of 
agronomic practices are suitable, optimal, and sustainable; and  
(vii)  support  the  agricultural  economists  in  assessing  and  comparing  viable  farm 
practice alternatives. 
 
5.  Environmentalists.  An  international  environment  specialist  (Henan/Sanmenxia,  2 
person-months;  Shanxi,  2  person-months)  and  a  national  environment  specialist 
(Henan/Sanmenxia, 3 person-months; Shanxi, 3 person-months), with formal qualifications in 
environmental  impact  assessment  and  knowledge  of  the  PRC’s  laws  and  regulations  on 
agricultural and industrial pollution, will do the following: 
 
(i)  familiarize the Executing Agency and Implementing Agency with ADB processes 
for  environmental  assessments,  and  ADB's  Guidelines  for  Preparing  Initial 
Environment Examination for Category B Projects;2  
(ii)  evaluate the potential impacts from the project activities (including soil excavation, 
spoil disposal, noise, and wastes) and identify appropriate mitigation measures;   
(iii)  together with the agronomist, assess possible environmental and social impacts of 
project  intervention  on  water  balance  for  different  types  of  crops  including 
(a) survey  the  environmental  problems  related  to  water  use  from  the  project 
intervention, (b) analyze the potential increased water demand from the expansion 
of  economic  crops  and  fast-growing  tree  plantation,  (c)  evaluate  the  water 
management system (irrigation system and user charge policies), and (d) identify 
possible mitigation measures for minimizing the negative impacts; 
(iv)  review  national  environmental  regulation  and  standards  related  to  agriculture 
development, including (a) agro-chemical regulations, (b) water quality standards 
of agro-processing, (c) planning regulations, and (d) international conventions;    
(v)  assess the environmental implications from the project of agro-chemical use; 
(vi)  evaluate  farmers’  readiness  to  safely  apply  agro-chemicals;  and  evaluate 
prospects for integrated pest management and organic fertilizer utilization in the 
province; 
(vii)  identify measures and needs for strengthening the agriculture extension service 
need to promote minimizing agro-chemical utilization; 
(viii)  assess crop residues and agro-processing wastes from project area production, 
and identify appropriate mitigate measures for disposal of wastes; and  
(ix)  prepare a summary initial environment examination, environmental management 
plan  including  a  description  of  each  mitigation  measure  and  cost  estimation, 
environmental monitoring plan, institutional arrangement, implementation schedule, 
and public discussion.   
 
6.  Rural  Finance,  Financial  Management,  and  Governance  Specialists:  An 
international  rural  finance  specialist  (Henan/Sanmenxia,  1.5  person-months;  Shanxi,  1.5 
person-months) together with a national financial analyst (Henan/Sanmenxia, 2 person-months; 
Shanxi, 2 person-months) will do the following:3   
                                                 
2  In carrying out the assessment, the consultant should use ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines. 
3  In carrying out analyses, the financial management specialist should use ADB’s Financial Management and 
Analysis of Projects as guidance.

14    Appendix 4 
 
(i)  assess how agro-enterprises in Sanmenxia have raised capital to develop their 
processing facilities from government, development banks, commercial banks, own 
capital, and foreign capital sources; 
(ii)  using  available  information,  identify  channels  for  lending  to  agro-enterprise 
farmers, and assess lending performance to the sector including lending volumes, 
types of businesses supported, and repayment performance;  
(iii)  assess  reasons  for  limited  access  by  potential  rural  enterprise  borrowers  to 
commercial banking and development banking and other formal banking sources;  
(iv)  identify and compare possible channels for supplying public funds and foreign loan 
capital  with  agro-enterprises  including  (a)  onlending  by  financial  bureaus, 
onlending through development or commercial banks, (b) loan guarantee systems, 
and  (c)  bidding  systems;  and  compare  likely  transactions  costs,  risks,  and 
channels that are likely to develop the rural financial market with those that may 
distort markets; 
(v)  recommend the channel most suitable for lending to agro-enterprises under the 
proposed  project  and  justify  its  selection,  and  demonstrate  how  the  selected 
channel will lower transaction costs; 
(vi)  assess the proposed in-kind and/or cash-based onlending system through agro-
enterprises  to  farmers  through  the  project,  and  compare  this  with  available 
alternatives such as direct lending by (a) rural credit cooperatives, (b) financial 
bureaus, and (c) other available channels; 
(vii)  recommend the channel that is most suitable for lending to farmers under the 
proposed project and justify its selection; 
(viii)  assess the financial performance of selected, candidate rural and agro-enterprises 
to be supported or associated with the project and assist in preparing criteria for 
selecting financially viable enterprises; and  
(ix)  carry  out  a  financial  management  assessment  of  the  Executing  Agency  and 
implementing  agencies  to  assess  the  affordability  and  suitability  of  financial 
management  systems  (including  accounting  and  auditing),  and  fund-flow 
arrangements needed to efficiently and effectively implement an ADB-financed 
project.  
 
7.  Agricultural Economists: The international agricultural economist (Henan/Sanmenxia, 
4  person-months;  Shanxi,  3.5  person-months)  and  the  national  agricultural  economist 
(Henan/Sanmenxia, 3 person-months; Shanxi, 4 person-months) will do the following:4 
 
(i)  analyze the government’s feasibility study (conducted by local agencies) on which 
the PRC loan proposal is based, with specific attention to financial and economic 
viability; 
(ii)  review  underlying  assumptions  from  available  sector  analyses,  discuss  with 
stakeholders (including authors of the feasibility study), and formally report on 
findings of viability and suggestions for change; 
(iii)  assess sector and subsector performance and assist the team leader in carrying 
out market assessments for targeted enterprises and the medium term market 
prospects for targeted enterprises; 
(iv)  review existing data on farmer incomes in the project area, in conjunction with rural 
sociologist; and conduct the baseline data review and survey to understand likely 
trends that this Project would have on farmer incomes and welfare;  
(v)  carry out microeconomic analysis of farm household production conditions and 
performance  in  relation  to  market  demand  and  value  chains  for  farms  and 
agroprocessing  enterprises,  and  compare  alternative  production  methods  for 
improved soil and water management proposed by the agronomists for financial 
and economic viability in the context of sector and macroeconomic trends; 
(vi)  assist the team leader in preparing the agro- and farm-enterprise selection criteria;  
(vii)  prepare project costs and financing plans in collaboration with the financial analyst;  
                                                 
4  In carrying out analyses, the agricultural economists should refer to ADB. 2005. Technical Note No. 14: Assessing 
Aid for a Sector Development Plan: Economic Analysis of a Sector Loan and ADB’s Guidelines for Economic 
Analysis of Projects. Manila.

Appendix 4  15
     
(viii)  conduct an appropriate financial feasibility and economic cost benefit analysis on 
selected agro and farm enterprises; 
(ix)  conduct sensitivity and risk analysis of possible pricing changes in factor inputs, 
output markets, including costs of water, fertilizers, energy, and labor; and 
(x)  conduct a distribution analysis among key stakeholders of the costs and benefits of 
the project. 
 
8.  Rural  Sociology  and  Farmer  Organizations  Specialists:  The  international  rural 
sociologist/farmer  organizations  specialist  (Henan/Sanmenxia,  2  person-months;  Shanxi,  2 
person-months)  together  with  the  national  rural  sociologist  (Henan/Sanmenxia,  2  person-
months; Shanxi, 2 person-months) the international consultant will do the following:5 
 
(i)  prepare a poverty and social assessment of the beneficiaries and stakeholders, 
identifying the main constraints to improving farmers’ livelihoods; 
(ii)  identify any instances where proposed activities trigger the need for resettlement 
and prepare needed plans that meet ADB safeguard policies and requirements for 
involuntary resettlement;  
(iii)  assess the numbers and status of any ethnic minorities in the project area and 
prepare  the  appropriate  ethnic  minority  development  plans  in  line  with  ADB’s 
safeguard policies as needed;  
(iv)  establish  the  baseline  against  which  the  project  impacts  on  welfare  may  be 
monitored  with  appropriate  monitoring  indicators,  and  help  design  the  repeat 
household survey to be carried out during implementation; and support the team 
leader in designing a sound monitoring system to track project implementation and 
use of resources;  
(v)  conduct participatory workshops with farmers and other participants in the rural 
value chain to (a) understand how the farming and marketing systems affect the 
economic  and  social  conditions  of  the  different  segments  of  the  farming 
community,  (b)  identify  the  present  forms  of  formal  and  informal  social  and 
economic  organization  practiced  by  farmers,  and  (c)  examine  the  impact  of 
membership in such local groups and associations on farmers’ livelihoods and 
incomes; 
(vi)  identify the formal and informal arrangements that govern the use of land and 
water resources, including common resources, as well as map resource use in the 
project area in terms of purpose, intensity of use, access by different segments of 
the  farming  community;  and  analyze  the  dynamics  of  poverty  in  terms  of 
marginalization and access to resources; 
(vii)  identify organizational and contractual forms that may be developed in the Project 
to promote effective participation of farmers in the rural value chain, equitable 
participation of women in decision-making and planning of development activities, 
and  capacity  building  or  institution-building  activities  for  farmers  and  farmers’ 
organizations considered necessary to ensure the successful implementation of 
the project (for example, to increase farmers’ negotiation skills and improve their 
access to market information); and develop a mechanism for recourse to address 
grievances; 
(viii)  review relevant past and present agriculture and rural development projects with 
regard  to  the  role  of  farmers’  organizations  and  increasing  the  benefits  from 
farmers’ participation in the rural value chain while ensuring their fair participation; 
and introduce, where appropriate to the local context, concepts drawn from lessons 
learned  and  international  best  practices  on  mobilizing  farmers  through  farmer 
organizations to connect with markets; 
(ix)  review relevant NGO and private sector interactions with farmers in the project 
area and identify possible roles in project implementation; and  
(x)  provide inputs to project design to address the constraints identified in the social 
and poverty assessment and review of the farming and marketing systems.
